thread.title: Texas & Neighbors: Pups (and humans) celebrate at Dogtoberfest in Beaumont
thread.title_full: Texas & Neighbors: Pups (and humans) celebrate at Dogtoberfest in Beaumont | Dallas Morning News

author: MARY DUNKLIN
title: Texas & Neighbors: Pups (and humans) celebrate at Dogtoberfest in Beaumont
text:
DURANT, OKLA. Choctaw Casino’s new complex adds family-friendly fun The District is a new place for families to play at Choctaw Casino Resort in Durant, Okla.
The entertainment complex includes a two-story laser tag arena, arcade and movie theater.
Also there’s a 20-lane bowling alley with glowing “cyberbowling” on Fridays and Saturdays from 9 p.m. to 2 a.m.
The District is open from 11 a.m. to midnight Sunday through Thursday, and 10 a.m. to 2 a.m. Friday and Saturday.
Contact: 4216 S. Highway 69/75, Durant, Okla.; choctawcasinos.com/choctaw-durant
HOUSTON Holiday market offers shopping with benefits Put your hair in a bun, slip on your ballet flats and get ready to shop till you drop at the 35th annual Houston Ballet Nutcracker Market. Attendees can browse through items from more than 300 merchants selling everything from food to furniture Nov. 12-15 at NRG Center.
Ticket sales start Oct. 19 for $18 each (plus surcharge) online through Ticketmaster. Tickets are good for one-day admission only. Half-price admission is available daily, three hours prior to closing. Children 5 and younger are free. Proceeds benefit the Houston Ballet Foundation.
Travel tip: Take advantage of the package-check booth to store your purchases and use the drive-through pickup service to make shopping easier.
Contact: 713-535-3231; houstonballet.org/nutcracker-market/
MESILLA, N.M. Day of the Dead comes alive at traditional fest Make plans to celebrate Día de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) in Mesilla, N.M. The town has the region’s largest celebration Oct. 30-Nov. 1 in Old Mesilla Plaza.
There will be arts vendors, music and activities for kids. Don’t miss the homemade altars prepared by local families in honor of departed loved ones. A candlelight procession at dusk takes place Nov. 2 to the San Albino Cemetery. Costumes or face paint are encouraged.
Contact: 575-647-2639
BEAUMONT Dogs and humans can celebrate at outdoor event Grab your leash, your family and your pups and head to downtown Beaumont from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m Oct. 10 for Dogtoberfest.
The event starts with a Puppies & Pancakes Breakfast, followed by a parade at 9 a.m. Several contests, including cutest, most talented and best howler (human or canine), will take place until 1 p.m. Other activities are a style show of adoptable dogs and parade of service dogs.
Pony rides, a petting zoo and food court will also be on site.
The event takes place at Central Bark (the green area between the Julie Rogers Theatre and Beaumont Public Library). Free entry and parking. A donation is required to compete in contests, participate in games and enjoy refreshments. Proceeds benefit the revitalization efforts of Beaumont’s historical downtown.Mary Dunklin
Contact: 409-838-2202; dogtoberfestbeaumont.com
